Thanks to everyone for tuning in and for asking so many great questions. It's an honor to serve as your representative in Washington.
"We want to make the tax process as simple as possible and allow people to give more to charity at the same time."
"Let's continue to work on making our tax code fairer, flatter, and simpler. It's an issue that we have to address to help all Americans."
The final question tonight comes from Susan in Plainview about tax reform.
"We have a lot of roads that need repair, and we need to make those investments."
Barbara from Staunton has a question regarding infrastructure.
"Continue to be an advocate (for bipartisanship). Rep's and Dem's do get along in DC, & most of what we vote on is truly bipartisan."
Vanessa had a questions about encouraging bipartisanship in today's political climate.
"I will work with the administration on enforcement of trade deals,but we can't pretend deals like NAFTA haven't been good for our economy."
"Trade is crucial to us selling our hometown products overseas. We must have incentives to have global trade opportunities to keep our jobs.
Terri called in with a question about NAFTA and trade issues.
"Coal has a valid and appropriate place in our national energy portfolio, and we'll fight to have those opportunities in the future."
"We'd love to see coal and clean coal technology continue be part of our energy portfolio.These are the energy investments we need to make."
Alan from Springfield has a question about coal jobs in Illinois.
"I'm proud to have sponsored HR 795, which allows companies to help graduates pay off student loan debt."https://rodneydavis.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=399248 …
"We've seen the staggering student loans that many families face. We must do more than just address the cost of college..."
Patrick from Calhoun County has a question about job opportunities for college graduates.
"I want those who commit the worst crimes to have the longest sentences. I want people to get the help they need over longer sentences."
"Atty General Sessions and I will disagree on the best ways to reform the criminal justice system."
"Criminal justice reform is something I've been talking about during my entire tenure in Congress. We must reform our mandatory minimums."
David from Edwardsville has a question about criminal justice reform.
"We need to ensure we have the educational resources and workforce to ensure these companies can continue to grow."
"We've seen what investment from companies like ADM have done to the Macon County economy."
Alan has a question regarding supporting local jobs.
"I hope we get bipartisanship in regard to fixing a broken tax code... I would like to see a revenue neutral tax reform plan."
"We have been stuck in an anemic economic growth rate... I want to see us grow our economy even more."
"I believe we need to be able to lower tax rates for middle class Americans and put more money in their pockets & close loopholes."
Pamela from Normal called to ask about tax cuts.
"Let's make sure we stop interference, not just in elections, but in any aspect of the US... our economy, cyber attack, & national defense."
"Any interference from any country needs to be investigated and stopped. Which is why you are seeing 3 investigations into Russian's role."
The next caller is Maria, who is asking about foreign influence in elections.
"I want to make our public education system stronger. Last Congress we did just that by reforming "No Child Left Behind" on bipartisan vote.
"I've never been a fan of vouchers proposed... They would not be beneficial to many of the schools in our district due to logistics issues."
Kenneth called to ask about school funding.
"I've always stood up and said I want to support pre-existing conditions."
"I've supported a bill that protects those with pre-existing conditions. The bill we passed has multiple layers of protection."
Evan called in with a question about healthcare and pre-existing conditions.
"The truth is that most bills that pass Congress pass with large bipartisan margins."
"I've seen our country come together in the midst of tragedies... If you just watched cable news, you'd think rep's and dem's don't talk."
"I've been ranked as one of the most moderate Congressman. I've got a reputation of working in a bipartisan way."
The next question comes from Doug in Springfield, who asks about alleviating the division between the political parties.
"It's a major issue we want to tackle. If you have any ideas on updating the tax code, please pass them along to my office."
"It contains many pages of loopholes that both parties talk about eliminating, and that's what we have the opportunity to do."
"Taxes are a major issue that we must address. We have a broken tax code that is way too onerous."
The first question of the evening comes from Stanley, who asks about tax relief at the federal level.

7of7 reasons to support #AHCA —> Cuts $600 billion in taxes on prescription drugs, medical devices & health plans which have increased costs
6of7 reasons to support #AHCA —> Allows young adults to remain on parents’ insurance until age 26
5of7 reasons to support #AHCA —> Medicaid expansion recipients in states like IL will cont to have coverage unless econ situation improves
4of7 reasons to support #AHCA —> Prevents insurance companies from discriminating against people w/ pre-existing conditions
3of7 reasons to support #AHCA —> Creates Patient&StateStabilityFund for high-risks pools, reduce out-of-pocket costs,&increase accessibility
2of7 reasons to support #AHCA —> Helps low-& mid-income (those left behind by #Obamacare) by providing portable age&income-based tax credits
1 of 7 reasons to support the #AHCA —> Repeals the individual and employer mandate that forced Americans to buy an unaffordable product

#TPAFact #20: #IL ranks 3 in the export of ag commodities to countries overseas & 2nd leading export of soybeans & feed grains.
#TPAFact #19: FTA markets generate export revenue of $54,800 for each American factory worker.
#TPAFact #18: The Asia-Pacific region will be home to 3.2 billion middle class consumers by 2020.
#TPAFact #17: Approx. 40% of all merchandise exports by U.S. small & medium-size enterprises go to FTA markets.

#TPAFact #16: Small and medium-sized companies account for 97% of all U.S. 
exporters.
#TPAFact #15: Every $1B of increased exports creates 5,000 higher paying #jobs.
#TPAFact #14: 14,000 #IL13 #jobs are supported by #trade.
#TPAFact #13: One in every 5 #jobs across the country depends on #trade.
#TPAFact #12: 300,000 IL #jobs are a direct result of #trade.
#TPAFact #11: More than 38 million American #jobs already depend on #trade.

#TPAFact #10: Gallup poll: 54% of Americans say trade represents 
an opportunity for economic growth through increased exports.
#TPAFact #9: 96% of the world’s customers live outside the United States.
#TPAFact #8: There have been 48 #trade agreements in Asia since 2000, and the U.S. is only a party to 2 of them.
#TPAFact #7: US has #trade surplus w/ 20 Free Trade Agreement (FTA) partners & trade deficit w/ countries we don't have trade agreement w/.
#TPAFact #5: Chair Ryan: Truth is, other countries won’t wait for US to elect a new pres. The world is writing the global economy right now.
#TPAFact #4: W/ exception of U.S.-Jordan FTA, U.S. has never entered into a free #trade agreement or multilateral #trade agreement w/o #TPA.
#TPAFact #3: Congress retains the ultimate authority to vote for–or reject– the final trade agreement.
#TPAFact #2: CRS confirms #TPA grants no new powers to the president
#TPAFact: 1st time establishes in law that text of a completed #trade agreement must be public for at least 60 days before the pres signs.
